messages.message: Unexpected lexical declaration in case block.

fix.text:
{ const weekAgo = new Date(now.getTime() - 7 * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000);
          return entryDate >= weekAgo; }

suggestions.desc: Add {} brackets around the case block.

messages.message: Unexpected lexical declaration in case block.

fix.text:
{ const monthAgo = new Date(now.getTime() - 30 * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000);
          return entryDate >= monthAgo; }

suggestions.desc: Add {} brackets around the case block.

messages.message: React Hook "React.useEffect" is called conditionally. React Hooks must be called in the exact same order in every component render.
Unnecessary escape character: \+.

suggestions.desc: Remove the `\`. This maintains the current functionality.
Replace the `\` with `\\` to include the actual backslash character.

messages.message: Unnecessary escape character: \*.

suggestions.desc: Remove the `\`. This maintains the current functionality.
Replace the `\` with `\\` to include the actual backslash character.

messages.message: Unnecessary escape character: \/.

suggestions.desc: Remove the `\`. This maintains the current functionality.
Replace the `\` with `\\` to include the actual backslash character.

messages.message: Irregular whitespace not allowed.

import React from 'react'; import oliveImage from '@/assets/olive-hickmott.png'; const EmpoweringLearningSection = () => { return

The Foundation of Empowering Learning.Â 

The foundation of our platform is the Empowering Learning model, created by Olive Hickmott, a forensic learning coach with decades of experience.

Neuroscience shows that fluent reading, spelling, and handwriting depend on building a Word Form Area (WFA) in the brain, near the occipital lobe where visual images are stored.

FPK University helps children grow their WFA by connecting visual memory to words, making learning natural, memorable, and enjoyable.

This approach has already helped thousands of children unlock their creativity, boost self-esteem, and rediscover the joy of learning.

Learn More About Empowering Learning
; }; export default EmpoweringLearningSection;

import React from 'react'; import { Card, CardContent, CardHeader, CardTitle } from '@/components/ui/card'; import { Badge } from '@/components/ui/badge'; import { Button } from '@/components/ui/button'; import { TrendingUp, Waves, BarChart3, Activity, Zap, Target } from 'lucide-react'; import { MicroLessonContainer } from '@/components/micro-lessons/MicroLessonContainer'; export const trigonometryGraphingLessonData = { id: 'trigonometry-graphing', moduleTitle: 'Graphing Trigonometric Functions', totalScreens: 8, screens: [ { id: 'welcome', type: 'concept' as const, title: 'From Circle to Waves: Graphing Trig Functions', content: (

Graphing Trigonometric Functions

Transform the unit circle into beautiful wave patterns that model the world around us!

ðŸŽ¯ What You'll Discover

How circular motion creates waves
Graphing sine and cosine functions
Understanding amplitude and period
Tangent function and its unique properties
Phase shifts and transformations
Real-world wave applications

Visual Revolution! You're about to see how the unit circle unfolds into the wave patterns that describe music, light, electricity, and so much more in our universe!

), estimatedTime: 2 }, { id: 'sine-wave-basics', type: 'concept', title: 'The Sine Wave: From Circle to Wave', content: (

The Sine Wave: From Circle to Wave

ðŸŒŠ Creating the Sine Wave

Imagine tracing a point as it moves around the unit circle. If you plot the y-coordinate (sine value) against the angle, you create the sine wave!

Key Properties of y = sin(x):

  • â€¢ Domain: All real numbers
  • â€¢ Range: [-1, 1]
  • â€¢ Period: 2Ï€ (360Â°)
  • â€¢ Amplitude: 1
  • â€¢ Starts at: (0, 0)
ã€°ï¸

The Classic Sine Wave

Pattern: 0 â†’ 1 â†’ 0 â†’ -1 â†’ 0

Smooth and continuous

Repeats every 2Ï€ units

ðŸ“ Key Points on the Sine Wave

x = 0

sin(0) = 0

Starting point

x = Ï€/2

sin(Ï€/2) = 1

Maximum

x = Ï€

sin(Ï€) = 0

Crosses axis

x = 3Ï€/2

sin(3Ï€/2) = -1

Minimum

ðŸ”„ The Repeating Pattern

The sine function is periodic with period 2Ï€. This means:

sin(x + 2Ï€) = sin(x) for any value of x

sin(0) = sin(2Ï€) = sin(4Ï€) = sin(-2Ï€) = 0

sin(Ï€/2) = sin(Ï€/2 + 2Ï€) = sin(Ï€/2 + 4Ï€) = 1

ðŸŽµ Real-World Connection

The sine wave is everywhere! It describes sound waves (musical notes), alternating current electricity, ocean waves, and even the motion of a swing. Nature loves sine waves because they represent the simplest form of oscillation.

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'cosine-wave-basics', type: 'concept', title: "The Cosine Wave: Sine's Twin", content: (

The Cosine Wave: Sine's Twin

ðŸŒŠ Creating the Cosine Wave

The cosine wave comes from plotting the x-coordinate (cosine value) of a point moving around the unit circle. It's almost identical to sine, but shifted!

Key Properties of y = cos(x):

  • â€¢ Domain: All real numbers
  • â€¢ Range: [-1, 1]
  • â€¢ Period: 2Ï€ (360Â°)
  • â€¢ Amplitude: 1
  • â€¢ Starts at: (0, 1) - Maximum!
ã€°ï¸

The Cosine Wave (starts high!)

Pattern: 1 â†’ 0 â†’ -1 â†’ 0 â†’ 1

Same shape as sine

But shifted left by Ï€/2

ðŸ“ Key Points on the Cosine Wave

x = 0

cos(0) = 1

Maximum start!

x = Ï€/2

cos(Ï€/2) = 0

Crosses axis

x = Ï€

cos(Ï€) = -1

Minimum

x = 3Ï€/2

cos(3Ï€/2) = 0

Back to axis

ðŸ”„ Sine vs. Cosine Relationship

Key Relationship

cos(x) = sin(x + Ï€/2)

Cosine is just sine shifted Ï€/2 units to the left. They're the same wave, just starting at different points!

Phase Difference

90Â° (or Ï€/2 radians) apart

When sine is at maximum, cosine is at zero. When sine is at zero, cosine is at maximum or minimum.

ðŸŽ¯ Comparison Table

Angle
sin(x)
cos(x)
0Â°
0
1
30Â°
1/2
âˆš3/2
45Â°
âˆš2/2
âˆš2/2
60Â°
âˆš3/2
1/2
90Â°
1
0
180Â°
0
-1
270Â°
-1
0

âš¡ Quick Recognition

Remember: Sine starts at 0 and goes up, Cosine starts at 1 and goes down. If you see a wave starting at its maximum, it's probably cosine!

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'tangent-function', type: 'concept', title: 'The Tangent Function: A Different Beast', content: (

The Tangent Function: A Different Beast

ðŸ“ˆ Understanding Tangent

The tangent function is different! It's not bounded like sine and cosine. Since tan(x) = sin(x)/cos(x), it goes to infinity when cosine equals zero.

Key Properties of y = tan(x):

  • â€¢ Domain: All reals except Ï€/2 + nÏ€
  • â€¢ Range: All real numbers
  • â€¢ Period: Ï€ (180Â°) - Half of sine/cosine!
  • â€¢ Vertical asymptotes at x = Ï€/2, 3Ï€/2, etc.
  • â€¢ Starts at: (0, 0)
ðŸ“ˆ

Tangent: Curves that go to infinity!

Pattern: 0 â†’ âˆž then -âˆž â†’ 0

Repeats every Ï€ units

Has vertical asymptotes

ðŸš« Vertical Asymptotes

Tangent has vertical asymptotes (undefined points) where cosine equals zero:

x = Ï€/2

cos(Ï€/2) = 0

tan(Ï€/2) = undefined

x = 3Ï€/2

cos(3Ï€/2) = 0

tan(3Ï€/2) = undefined

x = -Ï€/2

cos(-Ï€/2) = 0

tan(-Ï€/2) = undefined

x = 5Ï€/2

cos(5Ï€/2) = 0

tan(5Ï€/2) = undefined

Visual Tip: Near these asymptotes, the tangent curve shoots up to +âˆž on one side and down to -âˆž on the other side, creating a dramatic vertical line!

ðŸ“ Key Points on Tangent

Zero Points

tan(0) = 0

tan(Ï€) = 0

tan(2Ï€) = 0

Crosses x-axis

Special Values

tan(Ï€/4) = 1

tan(Ï€/3) = âˆš3

tan(Ï€/6) = 1/âˆš3

Memorable points

Asymptotes

x = Ï€/2 + nÏ€

where n is any integer

Undefined points

ðŸŽ¯ Why Tangent is Special

Tangent represents slope! At any point on the unit circle, tan(Î¸) gives the slope of the line from the origin to that point. This makes tangent perfect for describing steepness, rates of change, and angular relationships in engineering and physics.

), estimatedTime: 5 }, { id: 'amplitude-period', type: 'concept', title: 'Amplitude and Period: Controlling the Waves', content: (

Amplitude and Period: Controlling the Waves

ðŸ“ Amplitude: How High the Wave Goes

Amplitude controls the height of the wave. For y = AÂ·sin(x) or y = AÂ·cos(x):

  • â€¢ |A| = amplitude (always positive)
  • â€¢ If A {'>'} 0: normal orientation
  • â€¢ If A {'<'} 0: flipped upside down
  • â€¢ Range becomes [-|A|, |A|]

Real-world: Amplitude represents volume (sound), brightness (light), or intensity (radio waves).

y = 2sin(x)

Amplitude = 2

Range: [-2, 2]

Twice as tall!

y = 0.5cos(x)

Amplitude = 0.5

Range: [-0.5, 0.5]

Half as tall!

y = -3sin(x)

Amplitude = 3

Range: [-3, 3]

Flipped and tall!

ðŸ”„ Period: How Often the Wave Repeats

Period controls how quickly the wave repeats. For y = sin(Bx) or y = cos(Bx):

  • â€¢ Period = 2Ï€/|B|
  • â€¢ If |B| {'>'} 1: wave compresses (faster)
  • â€¢ If |B| {'<'} 1: wave stretches (slower)
  • â€¢ If B {'<'} 0: reflection about y-axis

y = sin(2x): Period = Ï€ (half as long)

y = sin(x/2): Period = 4Ï€ (twice as long)

y = sin(3x): Period = 2Ï€/3 (third as long)

ðŸŽµ Combined Transformations

y = AÂ·sin(Bx)

â€¢ Amplitude = |A|

â€¢ Period = 2Ï€/|B|

â€¢ Range = [-|A|, |A|]

Example: y = 3sin(2x)

â€¢ Amplitude = 3

â€¢ Period = 2Ï€/2 = Ï€

â€¢ Range = [-3, 3]

Tall and fast!

ðŸŒŠ Real-World Examples

Ocean Waves

Large amplitude = tall waves, short period = frequent waves

Sound Waves

Large amplitude = loud sound, short period = high pitch

AC Electricity

Amplitude = voltage level, period = frequency (60 Hz in US)

âš¡ Quick Check

Remember: Amplitude affects HEIGHT (how far up/down), Period affects WIDTH (how spread out). Think "tall and skinny" vs "short and wide" waves!

), estimatedTime: 5 }, { id: 'phase-shifts', type: 'concept', title: 'Phase Shifts and Vertical Shifts', content: (

Phase Shifts and Vertical Shifts

â†”ï¸ Phase Shifts: Moving Left and Right

Phase shift moves the entire wave left or right. For y = sin(x - C):

  • â€¢ If C {'>'} 0: shift RIGHT by C units
  • â€¢ If C {'<'} 0: shift LEFT by |C| units
  • â€¢ The wave keeps its shape, just moves
  • â€¢ Also called "horizontal translation"

Memory trick: y = sin(x - Ï€/2) shifts RIGHT Ï€/2 units, which turns sine into negative cosine!

y = sin(x - Ï€/4)

Shifts RIGHT Ï€/4

Delayed start

y = cos(x + Ï€/3)

Shifts LEFT Ï€/3

Early start

y = sin(x - Ï€/2)

Shifts RIGHT Ï€/2

= -cos(x)

â†•ï¸ Vertical Shifts: Moving Up and Down

Vertical shift moves the entire wave up or down. For y = sin(x) + D:

  • â€¢ If D {'>'} 0: shift UP by D units
  • â€¢ If D {'<'} 0: shift DOWN by |D| units
  • â€¢ Changes the midline (center line)
  • â€¢ New range: [min+D, max+D]

Real-world: Vertical shifts represent baseline values - like average temperature with daily fluctuations!

y = sin(x) + 2

Shifts UP 2 units

Range: [1, 3]

Elevated wave

y = cos(x) - 1

Shifts DOWN 1 unit

Range: [-2, 0]

Lowered wave

y = 2sin(x) + 3

Amplitude 2, up 3

Range: [1, 5]

Tall and high!

ðŸŽ¯ Complete Transformation Formula

y = AÂ·sin(B(x - C)) + D

A

Amplitude

Height control

B

Period = 2Ï€/|B|

Speed control

C

Phase shift

Left/right move

D

Vertical shift

Up/down move

ðŸ“ Example Analysis

y = 3sin(2(x - Ï€/4)) + 1

Amplitude: 3

Wave is 3 units tall

Period: Ï€

2Ï€/2 = Ï€ units long

Phase: Ï€/4 right

Starts Ï€/4 units later

Vertical: +1

Centered at y = 1

Range: [1-3, 1+3] = [-2, 4]

ðŸŽµ Musical Connection

These transformations are like adjusting a stereo: amplitude is volume, period is pitch, phase shift is delay/echo, and vertical shift is the baseline or DC offset. Every wave in nature can be described this way!

), estimatedTime: 5 }, { id: 'lesson-summary', type: 'summary', title: 'Wave Master: You Can Graph Any Trigonometric Function!', content: (

ðŸŽ‰ Incredible! You've Mastered the Art of Trigonometric Graphing

ðŸ† Your Wave-Riding Skills:

  • âœ… Creating sine and cosine waves from the unit circle
  • âœ… Understanding tangent's unique asymptotic behavior
  • âœ… Controlling amplitude (height) and period (speed)
  • âœ… Mastering phase shifts (left/right movement)
  • âœ… Applying vertical shifts (up/down movement)
  • âœ… Analyzing complex transformations y = AÂ·sin(B(x-C))+D
  • âœ… Connecting mathematical waves to real-world phenomena
  • âœ… Recognizing wave patterns in nature and technology

ðŸŒŠ Your Transformation Toolkit:

Amplitude

Controls wave height

Period

Controls wave speed

Phase Shift

Moves wave left/right

Vertical Shift

Moves wave up/down

ðŸš€ Coming Up Next:

Now that you can visualize trigonometric functions, you're ready to explore the relationships between different trig functions:

  • â€¢ Fundamental trigonometric identities
  • â€¢ How to prove and use these powerful relationships
  • â€¢ Simplifying complex trigonometric expressions
  • â€¢ Building the foundation for solving trig equations

ðŸŽ¼ The Universal Language

You've just learned the universal language of oscillation! Every vibrating string, radio wave, heartbeat, brain wave, and planetary orbit can be described using the trigonometric functions you now understand. You're seeing the mathematics that makes the universe dance!

), estimatedTime: 3 } ] }; interface TrigonometryGraphingMicroLessonProps { onComplete?: () => void; } const TrigonometryGraphingMicroLesson: React.FC = ({ onComplete }) => { return ( ); }; export default TrigonometryGraphingMicroLesson;

import React from 'react'; import { Card, CardContent, CardHeader, CardTitle } from '@/components/ui/card'; import { Badge } from '@/components/ui/badge'; import { Button } from '@/components/ui/button'; import { Calculator, Triangle, BookOpen, Target, AlertCircle, Award } from 'lucide-react'; import { MicroLessonContainer } from '@/components/micro-lessons/MicroLessonContainer'; export const trigonometryIntroductionLessonData = { id: 'trigonometry-introduction', moduleTitle: 'Introduction to Trigonometry', totalScreens: 8, screens: [ { id: 'welcome', type: 'concept' as const, title: 'Welcome to Trigonometry!', content: (

Introduction to Trigonometry

Discover the fascinating world of trigonometry - the mathematics of triangles, waves, and rotations!

ðŸŽ¯ What You'll Learn

What trigonometry is and why it matters
Understanding right triangles
The unit circle concept
Key angles and their importance
Real-world applications
Building foundation for advanced concepts

Pro Tip: Trigonometry connects geometry with algebra and appears everywhere in science, engineering, and even art. Master these basics to unlock advanced mathematics!

), estimatedTime: 2 }, { id: 'what-is-trigonometry', type: 'concept', title: 'What is Trigonometry?', content: (

What is Trigonometry?

ðŸ“š Definition

Trigonometry is the branch of mathematics that studies the relationships between angles and sides in triangles. The word comes from Greek: "trigon" (triangle) + "metron" (measure).

In simple terms:

Trigonometry helps us find unknown sides or angles in triangles when we know some information about them.

Engineering

Building bridges, designing structures

Navigation

GPS, sailing, aviation

Physics

Waves, oscillations, forces

Fun Fact: Ancient Egyptians used trigonometry to build pyramids, and today it powers everything from video games to satellite communications!

), estimatedTime: 3 }, { id: 'right-triangles', type: 'concept', title: 'Right Triangles: The Foundation', content: (

Right Triangles: The Foundation

ðŸ”º What Makes a Right Triangle Special?

Right triangles are the foundation of trigonometry. They have one 90Â° angle and two acute angles that sum to 90Â°.

Hypotenuse: The longest side (opposite the 90Â° angle)
Opposite: The side opposite to the angle we're studying
Adjacent: The side next to the angle we're studying
ðŸ“

Imagine this as a right triangle - the corner represents the 90Â° angle

ðŸŽ¯ Key Properties

  • âœ… One angle is exactly 90Â°
  • âœ… The other two angles sum to 90Â°
  • âœ… Hypotenuse is always the longest side
  • âœ… Pythagorean theorem applies: aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ²
  • âœ… Foundation for all trigonometric ratios
  • âœ… Appears everywhere in real applications

ðŸ’¡ Memory Aid

Think of a right triangle as a "corner" - like the corner of a room where two walls meet the floor. That corner is always 90Â°, and the triangular space forms our right triangle!

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'triangle-sides', type: 'example', title: 'Identifying Triangle Sides', content: (

Identifying Triangle Sides

ðŸŽ¯ The Three Sides Explained

Hypotenuse

â€¢ Always the longest side
â€¢ Opposite the 90Â° angle
â€¢ Never changes identity

Opposite

â€¢ Opposite to your chosen angle
â€¢ Changes based on which angle you're studying
â€¢ Not the hypotenuse

Adjacent

â€¢ Next to your chosen angle
â€¢ Changes based on which angle you're studying
â€¢ Not the hypotenuse

ðŸ“ Example Walkthrough

In a right triangle, if we're looking at angle A (not the 90Â° angle):

ðŸ”´ Hypotenuse: The side opposite the 90Â° angle (always the same)

ðŸ”µ Opposite to A: The side that doesn't touch angle A

ðŸŸ¢ Adjacent to A: The side that touches angle A (but isn't the hypotenuse)

âš¡ Quick Check

Which side is always the longest in a right triangle?

Answer: The hypotenuse (opposite the 90Â° angle)

Do opposite and adjacent sides change?

Answer: Yes! They depend on which angle you're studying

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'unit-circle-intro', type: 'concept', title: 'Introduction to the Unit Circle', content: (

Introduction to the Unit Circle

â­• What is the Unit Circle?

The unit circle is a circle with radius 1, centered at the origin (0,0) of a coordinate plane. It's the most important tool in trigonometry!

Key Properties:

  • â€¢ Radius = 1 unit
  • â€¢ Center at (0, 0)
  • â€¢ Circumference = 2Ï€
  • â€¢ Every point is distance 1 from center
â­•

The unit circle - radius = 1

Center: (0, 0)

Any point on circle: distance 1 from center

ðŸŽ¯ Why is it So Important?

Connects angles to coordinates
Makes trig functions visual
Works for all angles (not just 0Â°-90Â°)
Foundation for advanced topics
Used in physics and engineering
Essential for understanding waves

ðŸ”® Preview

Soon you'll see how every point on the unit circle gives us the values of sine and cosine for different angles. This connection between geometry and algebra is what makes trigonometry so powerful!

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'key-angles', type: 'reference', title: 'Important Angles to Remember', content: (

Important Angles to Remember

ðŸ“ The Special Angles

Certain angles appear frequently in trigonometry. Memorizing their values will save you time and build intuition.

0Â°

Starting point

â†’

Horizontal right

 30Â°, 45Â°, 60Â°

The "special" angles

ðŸ“

Common in problems

 90Â°

Right angle

â†‘

Vertical up

ðŸŒ Degrees vs. Radians

Angles can be measured in degrees (Â°) or radians. Both are important in trigonometry.

Degrees

Full circle = 360Â°

â€¢ 0Â° = Start

â€¢ 90Â° = Quarter turn

â€¢ 180Â° = Half turn

â€¢ 270Â° = Three-quarters

â€¢ 360Â° = Full circle

Radians

Full circle = 2Ï€

â€¢ 0 = Start

â€¢ Ï€/2 = Quarter turn

â€¢ Ï€ = Half turn

â€¢ 3Ï€/2 = Three-quarters

â€¢ 2Ï€ = Full circle

ðŸŽ¯ Study Tip

Don't worry about memorizing everything now! Focus on understanding the concepts. As we work through examples, these special values will become natural to you.

), estimatedTime: 3 }, { id: 'real-world-preview', type: 'example', title: 'Real-World Applications Preview', content: (

Real-World Applications Preview

ðŸŒ Where You'll Use Trigonometry

ðŸ—ï¸ Construction & Architecture

Calculating roof angles, stair slopes, and ensuring buildings are structurally sound.

ðŸ§­ Navigation

GPS systems, ship navigation, and flight paths all rely on trigonometric calculations.

ðŸŒŠ Physics & Waves

Sound waves, light waves, ocean waves - all described using trigonometric functions.

ðŸŽ® Computer Graphics

Video games, animations, and 3D modeling use trigonometry for rotations and movements.

ðŸŽ¯ Example Scenarios

Scenario 1: Finding Building Height

Standing 50 feet from a building, you measure a 60Â° angle to the top. How tall is the building?

Scenario 2: Satellite Communication

What angle should a satellite dish point to receive the strongest signal?

Scenario 3: Music & Sound

How do different musical notes create harmonies? It's all about wave frequencies!

ðŸš€ Your Journey Ahead

By the end of this course, you'll have the tools to solve all these real-world problems and more. Every concept we learn builds toward these practical applications!

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'lesson-summary', type: 'summary', title: 'Foundation Complete: Ready for Trigonometric Ratios!', content: (

ðŸŽ‰ Excellent! You've Built a Strong Foundation

ðŸ† What You've Mastered:

  • âœ… What trigonometry is and why it's important
  • âœ… Right triangle components (hypotenuse, opposite, adjacent)
  • âœ… How to identify triangle sides based on reference angles
  • âœ… Introduction to the unit circle concept
  • âœ… Key angles in degrees and radians
  • âœ… Real-world applications overview
  • âœ… The connection between geometry and algebra
  • âœ… Why trigonometry appears in so many fields

ðŸŽ¯ Coming Up Next:

Now that you understand the foundation, you're ready to learn the three fundamental trigonometric ratios:

SINE

opposite/hypotenuse

COSINE

adjacent/hypotenuse

TANGENT

opposite/adjacent

ðŸ’¡ Key Insight

Remember: Trigonometry is about relationships. Once you see the patterns, everything becomes much clearer. You're building mathematical superpowers that will serve you throughout your academic and professional journey!

), estimatedTime: 3 } ] }; interface TrigonometryIntroductionMicroLessonProps { onComplete?: () => void; } const TrigonometryIntroductionMicroLesson: React.FC = ({ onComplete }) => { return ( ); }; export default TrigonometryIntroductionMicroLesson;

import React from 'react'; import { Card, CardContent, CardHeader, CardTitle } from '@/components/ui/card'; import { Badge } from '@/components/ui/badge'; import { Button } from '@/components/ui/button'; import { Calculator, Target, BookOpen, AlertCircle, CheckCircle, Trophy } from 'lucide-react'; import { MicroLessonContainer } from '@/components/micro-lessons/MicroLessonContainer'; export const trigonometryRatiosLessonData = { id: 'trigonometry-ratios', moduleTitle: 'Sine, Cosine, and Tangent', totalScreens: 8, screens: [ { id: 'welcome', type: 'concept' as const, title: 'The Big Three: Sin, Cos, and Tan', content: (

Sine, Cosine, and Tangent

Master the three fundamental trigonometric ratios that unlock all of trigonometry!

ðŸŽ¯ What You'll Learn

The SOHCAHTOA mnemonic
How to calculate sine, cosine, tangent
When to use each ratio
Step-by-step problem solving
Calculator usage and techniques
Real-world problem applications

Get Ready! You're about to learn the most important concept in trigonometry. Once you master these three ratios, you can solve almost any triangle problem!

), estimatedTime: 2 }, { id: 'sohcahtoa', type: 'concept', title: 'SOHCAHTOA: The Magic Formula', content: (

SOHCAHTOA: The Magic Formula

SOHCAHTOA

The most important mnemonic in trigonometry!

SOH

Sine = Opposite/Hypotenuse

sin(Î¸) = O/H

 CAH

Cosine = Adjacent/Hypotenuse

cos(Î¸) = A/H

 TOA

Tangent = Opposite/Adjacent

tan(Î¸) = O/A

ðŸ§  Memory Tricks

Classic: SOHCAHTOA

{'"Some Old Hippie Caught Another Hippie Tripping On Acid"'}

Alternative

{'"Silly Old Harry Caught A Herring Trawling Off America"'}

Choose whichever phrase helps you remember best, or create your own!

ðŸŽ¯ The Key Insight

These aren't just formulas - they're relationships! Each ratio tells us something specific about the triangle's shape. The same angle in any right triangle will always give the same ratios.

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'sine-explained', type: 'concept', title: 'Understanding Sine', content: (

Understanding Sine

ðŸ“ Sine: The Vertical Component

sin(Î¸) = Opposite/Hypotenuse

Sine measures how much of the hypotenuse is in the vertical direction compared to the angle.

When sin(Î¸) = 0.5

The opposite side is half the length of the hypotenuse

When sin(Î¸) = 1

The triangle is "flat" - angle is 90Â°

When sin(Î¸) = 0

The triangle is "flat" - angle is 0Â°

Common Sine Values

sin(30Â°) 0.5
sin(45Â°) 0.707
sin(60Â°) 0.866
sin(90Â°) 1.0

ðŸŽ¯ When to Use Sine

You Know:

  • â€¢ An angle
  • â€¢ The hypotenuse length

You Want:

  • â€¢ The opposite side length

Or You Know:

  • â€¢ The opposite side
  • â€¢ The hypotenuse

You Want:

  • â€¢ The angle

ðŸ’¡ Visual Tip

Think of sine as measuring "height." If you're looking up at something, sine tells you how much of your line of sight is vertical. This is why sine is used for heights, elevations, and vertical distances!

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'cosine-explained', type: 'concept', title: 'Understanding Cosine', content: (

Understanding Cosine

ðŸ“ Cosine: The Horizontal Component

cos(Î¸) = Adjacent/Hypotenuse

Cosine measures how much of the hypotenuse is in the horizontal direction relative to the angle.

When cos(Î¸) = 1

The adjacent side equals the hypotenuse (angle = 0Â°)

When cos(Î¸) = 0.5

The adjacent side is half the hypotenuse length

When cos(Î¸) = 0

No horizontal component (angle = 90Â°)

Common Cosine Values

cos(0Â°) 1.0
cos(30Â°) 0.866
cos(45Â°) 0.707
cos(60Â°) 0.5
cos(90Â°) 0.0

ðŸŽ¯ When to Use Cosine

You Know:

  • â€¢ An angle
  • â€¢ The hypotenuse length

You Want:

  • â€¢ The adjacent side length

Or You Know:

  • â€¢ The adjacent side
  • â€¢ The hypotenuse

You Want:

  • â€¢ The angle

ðŸ’¡ Visual Tip

Think of cosine as measuring "distance." If you're walking toward something, cosine tells you how much of your path is horizontal. This is why cosine is used for horizontal distances, shadows, and ground coverage!

ðŸ”— Sine & Cosine Connection

Notice: sinÂ²(Î¸) + cosÂ²(Î¸) = 1. This means sine and cosine are complementary - they always work together to describe the complete triangle!

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'tangent-explained', type: 'concept', title: 'Understanding Tangent', content: (

Understanding Tangent

ðŸ“ Tangent: The Slope Ratio

tan(Î¸) = Opposite/Adjacent

Tangent measures the steepness or slope of the angle. It's the ratio of "rise over run."

When tan(Î¸) = 1

45Â° angle - rise equals run (slope = 1)

When tan(Î¸) {'>'}; 1

Steep angle - more rise than run

When tan(Î¸) {'<'} 1

Shallow angle - more run than rise

Common Tangent Values

tan(0Â°) 0.0
tan(30Â°) 0.577
tan(45Â°) 1.0
tan(60Â°) 1.732
tan(90Â°) âˆž

ðŸŽ¯ When to Use Tangent

Perfect for:

  • â€¢ Finding angles of elevation
  • â€¢ Calculating slopes and grades
  • â€¢ When hypotenuse is unknown
  • â€¢ Ramp and stair problems

Bonus Feature:

Tangent doesn't need the hypotenuse! If you only know the two legs of a right triangle, tangent can still find angles.

ðŸ’¡ Real-World Connection

Tangent is everywhere! Road grades (6% grade means tan(angle) = 0.06), roof pitches (4:12 pitch means tan(angle) = 4/12), and even smartphone tilt sensors use tangent values.

ðŸ”— Special Relationship

Here's a secret: tan(Î¸) = sin(Î¸)/cos(Î¸). Tangent is actually just sine divided by cosine! This relationship will become very useful later.

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'problem-solving-steps', type: 'example', title: 'Step-by-Step Problem Solving', content: (

Step-by-Step Problem Solving

ðŸŽ¯ The Universal Method

Step 1: Draw & Label

â€¢ Draw the right triangle
â€¢ Mark the right angle
â€¢ Label known sides/angles
â€¢ Mark what you're looking for

Step 2: Identify

â€¢ Which angle are you using?
â€¢ Which sides are opposite, adjacent, hypotenuse?
â€¢ What do you know? What do you need?

Step 3: Choose Ratio

â€¢ SOH: Use sine (O/H)
â€¢ CAH: Use cosine (A/H)
â€¢ TOA: Use tangent (O/A)
â€¢ Pick the one matching your known/unknown

Step 4: Solve

â€¢ Set up the equation
â€¢ Substitute known values
â€¢ Solve for the unknown
â€¢ Check your answer makes sense

ðŸ“ Example Problem

A ladder leans against a wall at a 60Â° angle. The ladder is 10 feet long. How high up the wall does it reach?

Step 1: Draw & Label

Right triangle: wall, ground, ladder. Angle = 60Â°, hypotenuse = 10 ft

Step 2: Identify

Want: height (opposite to 60Â°). Know: hypotenuse = 10 ft

Step 3: Choose Ratio

Need opposite/hypotenuse = sine. Use SOH!

Step 4: Solve

sin(60Â°) = height/10
height = 10 Ã— sin(60Â°) = 10 Ã— 0.866 = 8.66 ft

ðŸŽ¯ Pro Tips

  • â€¢ Always draw a diagram - it prevents confusion
  • â€¢ Label everything you know before choosing a formula
  • â€¢ Double-check which side is opposite/adjacent to your angle
  • â€¢ Make sure your calculator is in the right mode (degrees vs radians)
), estimatedTime: 5 }, { id: 'calculator-tips', type: 'example', title: 'Calculator Usage and Inverse Functions', content: (

Calculator Usage and Inverse Functions

ðŸ”¢ Calculator Basics

Finding Ratios

sin(30Â°): 30 [SIN] = 0.5

cos(45Â°): 45 [COS] = 0.707

tan(60Â°): 60 [TAN] = 1.732

 Mode Check

Always verify: DEG mode for degrees, RAD mode for radians. Most problems use degrees unless specified otherwise.

Finding Angles (Inverse)

sinâ»Â¹(0.5): 0.5 [SINâ»Â¹] = 30Â°

cosâ»Â¹(0.707): 0.707 [COSâ»Â¹] = 45Â°

tanâ»Â¹(1.732): 1.732 [TANâ»Â¹] = 60Â°

 Inverse Notation

sinâ»Â¹, arcsin, asin all mean the same thing. Different calculators use different notation.

ðŸ”„ Forward vs. Inverse Functions

Forward (Angle â†’ Ratio)

Given: Angle

Find: Trigonometric ratio

Use: sin, cos, tan buttons

Example: sin(30Â°) = 0.5

Inverse (Ratio â†’ Angle)

Given: Trigonometric ratio

Find: Angle

Use: sinâ»Â¹, cosâ»Â¹, tanâ»Â¹ buttons

Example: sinâ»Â¹(0.5) = 30Â°

âš¡ Quick Practice

Try this: What's cos(60Â°)?

Answer: 0.5 (or exactly 1/2)

Now try: What angle has sin(Î¸) = 0.707?

Answer: Î¸ = sinâ»Â¹(0.707) = 45Â°

âš ï¸ Common Calculator Mistakes

  • â€¢ Wrong mode (degrees vs radians)
  • â€¢ Forgetting parentheses: sin(30Â°) not sin30Â°
  • â€¢ Confusing sinâ»Â¹ with 1/sin (they're different!)
  • â€¢ Not checking if answers make sense
), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'lesson-summary', type: 'summary', title: "SOHCAHTOA Mastered: You're Ready for Advanced Trigonometry!", content: (

ðŸŽ‰ Outstanding! You've Mastered the Foundation of Trigonometry

ðŸ† What You've Conquered:

  • âœ… SOHCAHTOA mnemonic and its meaning
  • âœ… Sine: opposite/hypotenuse relationship
  • âœ… Cosine: adjacent/hypotenuse relationship
  • âœ… Tangent: opposite/adjacent relationship
  • âœ… When to use each trigonometric ratio
  • âœ… Step-by-step problem-solving method
  • âœ… Calculator techniques and inverse functions
  • âœ… Common values and practical applications

ðŸŽ¯ Your Trigonometric Arsenal:

SINE

Height finder

Vertical component

COSINE

Distance finder

Horizontal component

TANGENT

Slope finder

Steepness measure

ðŸš€ Coming Up Next:

Now that you're a SOHCAHTOA expert, you're ready to explore how these ratios work on the unit circle, opening up a whole new world of possibilities:

  • â€¢ Understanding angles beyond 90Â°
  • â€¢ Visualizing trig functions on the coordinate plane
  • â€¢ Connecting geometry with algebra
  • â€¢ Preparing for graphing and periodic functions

ðŸ’ª Power User Status Unlocked!

You can now solve any right triangle problem! Whether it's finding missing sides, calculating angles, or tackling real-world applications, you have the tools. The mathematical universe just got a lot more accessible!

), estimatedTime: 3 } ] }; interface TrigonometryRatiosMicroLessonProps { onComplete?: () => void; } const TrigonometryRatiosMicroLesson: React.FC = ({ onComplete }) => { return ( ); }; export default TrigonometryRatiosMicroLesson;

source:
import React from 'react'; import { Card, CardContent, CardHeader, CardTitle } from '@/components/ui/card'; import { Badge } from '@/components/ui/badge'; import { Button } from '@/components/ui/button'; import { Circle, Target, Compass, RotateCcw, Navigation, Award } from 'lucide-react'; import { MicroLessonContainer } from '@/components/micro-lessons/MicroLessonContainer'; export const trigonometryUnitCircleLessonData = { id: 'trigonometry-unit-circle', moduleTitle: 'Trigonometric Functions on the Unit Circle', totalScreens: 8, screens: [ { id: 'welcome', type: 'concept' as const, title: 'The Unit Circle: Your Trigonometry GPS', content: (

Trigonometric Functions on the Unit Circle

Discover how the unit circle transforms trigonometry from triangles to coordinates!

ðŸŽ¯ What You'll Master

Unit circle coordinates and angles
How sine and cosine become coordinates
Reference angles and symmetry
Angles beyond 90Â° (quadrants)
Special angle values and patterns
Connecting circles to triangles

Game Changer Ahead! The unit circle is where trigonometry becomes truly powerful. You'll see how everything connects and why trig functions work for any angle!

), estimatedTime: 2 }, { id: 'unit-circle-setup', type: 'concept', title: 'Setting Up the Unit Circle', content: (

Setting Up the Unit Circle

â­• The Perfect Circle

The unit circle is a circle with radius 1, centered at the origin (0,0). Every point on this circle is exactly 1 unit away from the center.

Key Properties:

  • â€¢ Center: (0, 0)
  • â€¢ Radius: 1 unit
  • â€¢ Equation: xÂ² + yÂ² = 1
  • â€¢ Circumference: 2Ï€ â‰ˆ 6.28
â­•

The Unit Circle

Any point (x,y) on the circle:

Distance from center = âˆš(xÂ² + yÂ²) = 1

ðŸ“ Coordinate Connection

Starting Point: (1, 0)

We start at the rightmost point of the circle: (1, 0). This corresponds to 0Â° or 0 radians.

Moving Counterclockwise

As we rotate counterclockwise, we create angles and trace out points on the circle.

ðŸŽ¯ The Magic Connection

For any angle Î¸ on the unit circle:

x-coordinate = cos(Î¸)

Horizontal position

y-coordinate = sin(Î¸)

Vertical position

This is the fundamental connection that makes everything work!

ðŸ’¡ Why This Matters

Now trigonometry isn't limited to right triangles! We can find sine and cosine values for ANY angle - even angles larger than 90Â° or negative angles. The unit circle is our universal tool.

), estimatedTime: 4 }, { id: 'coordinates-and-angles', type: 'example', title: 'Coordinates and Angles', content: (

Coordinates and Angles

ðŸ“ Key Angle Positions

0Â° (0)

(1, 0)

Start/East

 90Â° (Ï€/2)

(0, 1)

Top/North

 180Â° (Ï€)

(-1, 0)

Left/West

 270Â° (3Ï€/2)

(0, -1)

Bottom/South

ðŸŽ¯ Reading Coordinates

At 0Â°: cos(0Â°) = 1, sin(0Â°) = 0 â†’ Point (1, 0)

At 90Â°: cos(90Â°) = 0, sin(90Â°) = 1 â†’ Point (0, 1)

At 180Â°: cos(180Â°) = -1, sin(180Â°) = 0 â†’ Point (-1, 0)

At 270Â°: cos(270Â°) = 0, sin(270Â°) = -1 â†’ Point (0, -1)

ðŸ”„ Special Angles in All Quadrants

30Â° Family

30Â°: (âˆš3/2, 1/2)

150Â°: (-âˆš3/2, 1/2)

210Â°: (-âˆš3/2, -1/2)

330Â°: (âˆš3/2, -1/2)

45Â° Family

45Â°: (âˆš2/2, âˆš2/2)

135Â°: (-âˆš2/2, âˆš2/2)

225Â°: (-âˆš2/2, -âˆš2/2)

315Â°: (âˆš2/2, -âˆš2/2)

Pattern Recognition: Notice how the same values appear in different quadrants, just with different signs! This symmetry makes the unit circle predictable.

ðŸ§­ Navigation Tip

Think of the unit circle like a compass: East is 0Â°, North is 90Â°, West is 180Â°, South is 270Â°. The coordinates tell you exactly where you are on your circular journey!

), estimatedTime: 5 }, { id: 'quadrants-and-signs', type: 'concept', title: 'Quadrants and Sign Patterns', content: (

Quadrants and Sign Patterns

ðŸ—ºï¸ The Four Quadrants

Quadrant I

0Â° to 90Â°

Both x and y positive

cos(Î¸) {'>'}; 0, sin(Î¸) {'>'}; 0

âœ… All trig functions positive

 Quadrant II

90Â° to 180Â°

x negative, y positive

cos(Î¸) {'<'} 0, sin(Î¸) {'>'}; 0

âœ… Only sine positive

 Quadrant III

180Â° to 270Â°

Both x and y negative

cos(Î¸) {'<'} 0, sin(Î¸) {'<'} 0

âœ… Only tangent positive

 Quadrant IV

270Â° to 360Â°

x positive, y negative

cos(Î¸) {'>'}; 0, sin(Î¸) {'<'} 0

âœ… Only cosine positive

ðŸŽ¯ ASTC Memory Device

A

All positive

(Quadrant I)

S

Sine positive

(Quadrant II)

T

Tangent positive

(Quadrant III)

C

Cosine positive

(Quadrant IV)

Memory phrase: "All Students Take Calculus" or "All Smart Teachers Care"

ðŸ“ Examples in Each Quadrant

120Â° (Quadrant II)

sin(120Â°) = âˆš3/2 (positive)

cos(120Â°) = -1/2 (negative)

240Â° (Quadrant III)

sin(240Â°) = -âˆš3/2 (negative)

cos(240Â°) = -1/2 (negative)

300Â° (Quadrant IV)

sin(300Â°) = -âˆš3/2 (negative)

cos(300Â°) = 1/2 (positive)

60Â° (Quadrant I)

sin(60Â°) = âˆš3/2 (positive)

cos(60Â°) = 1/2 (positive)

ðŸ’¡ Quick Sign Check

Before calculating any trig value, determine which quadrant your angle is in. This tells you immediately whether your answer should be positive or negative!

), estimatedTime: 5 }, { id: 'reference-angles', type: 'concept', title: 'Reference Angles and Symmetry', content: (

Reference Angles and Symmetry

ðŸ”„ What Are Reference Angles?

A reference angle is the acute angle (0Â° to 90Â°) that an angle makes with the x-axis. It's always positive and always between 0Â° and 90Â°.

Purpose: Find trig values using symmetry

Rule: |sin Î¸| = sin(reference angle)

Rule: |cos Î¸| = cos(reference angle)

Finding Reference Angles

Quadrant I: Î¸ itself

Quadrant II: 180Â° - Î¸

Quadrant III: Î¸ - 180Â°

Quadrant IV: 360Â° - Î¸

ðŸ“ Reference Angle Examples

150Â° (Quadrant II)

Reference angle = 180Â° - 150Â° = 30Â°

So sin(150Â°) = sin(30Â°) = 1/2

But cos(150Â°) = -cos(30Â°) = -âˆš3/2

225Â° (Quadrant III)

Reference angle = 225Â° - 180Â° = 45Â°

So |sin(225Â°)| = sin(45Â°) = âˆš2/2

But sin(225Â°) = -âˆš2/2 (negative in Q III)

315Â° (Quadrant IV)

Reference angle = 360Â° - 315Â° = 45Â°

So cos(315Â°) = cos(45Â°) = âˆš2/2

But sin(315Â°) = -sin(45Â°) = -âˆš2/2

120Â° (Quadrant II)

Reference angle = 180Â° - 120Â° = 60Â°

So sin(120Â°) = sin(60Â°) = âˆš3/2

But cos(120Â°) = -cos(60Â°) = -1/2

ðŸŽ¯ The Reference Angle Method

  1. Step 1: Determine which quadrant your angle is in
  2. Step 2: Find the reference angle using the quadrant rules
  3. Step 3: Find the trig value of the reference angle
  4. Step 4: Apply the correct sign based on the quadrant (ASTC)

ðŸ” Symmetry Patterns

Even/Odd Functions

Cosine is even: cos(-Î¸) = cos(Î¸)

Sine is odd: sin(-Î¸) = -sin(Î¸)

Tangent is odd: tan(-Î¸) = -tan(Î¸)

Complementary Angles

sin(90Â° - Î¸) = cos(Î¸)

cos(90Â° - Î¸) = sin(Î¸)

This is why 30Â° and 60Â° have "swapped" values!

âš¡ Power Move

With reference angles, you only need to memorize the trig values for 30Â°, 45Â°, and 60Â°. Every other special angle can be found using symmetry!

), estimatedTime: 5 }, { id: 'beyond-90-degrees', type: 'example', title: 'Angles Beyond 90Â°', content: (

Angles Beyond 90Â°

ðŸš€ Breaking the 90Â° Barrier

With the unit circle, we're no longer limited to right triangles! We can find trigonometric values for any angle - even negative angles or angles greater than 360Â°.

Types of Angles:

  • â€¢ Acute: 0Â° to 90Â°
  • â€¢ Obtuse: 90Â° to 180Â°
  • â€¢ Reflex: 180Â° to 360Â°
  • â€¢ Negative: Clockwise rotation
  • â€¢ Coterminal: Differ by 360Â°

450Â° Example

450Â° = 360Â° + 90Â°

So 450Â° and 90Â° are coterminal

sin(450Â°) = sin(90Â°) = 1

-30Â° Example

-30Â° = 360Â° - 30Â° = 330Â°

Clockwise 30Â° = Counterclockwise 330Â°

cos(-30Â°) = cos(330Â°) = âˆš3/2

ðŸ”„ Coterminal Angles

Coterminal angles end at the same position on the unit circle. They have identical trig values.

Rule: Add or subtract 360Â° (or 2Ï€ radians) to find coterminal angles.

45Â°

405Â°, 765Â°, -315Â°

All have same trig values

60Â°

420Â°, 780Â°, -300Â°

All have same trig values

30Â°

390Â°, 750Â°, -330Â°

All have same trig values

ðŸ“ Extended Angle Examples

Find sin(210Â°)

210Â° is in Quadrant III (180Â° to 270Â°)

Reference angle = 210Â° - 180Â° = 30Â°

sin(210Â°) = -sin(30Â°) = -1/2 (negative in Q III)

Find cos(300Â°)

300Â° is in Quadrant IV (270Â° to 360Â°)

Reference angle = 360Â° - 300Â° = 60Â°

cos(300Â°) = cos(60Â°) = 1/2 (positive in Q IV)

Find tan(135Â°)

135Â° is in Quadrant II (90Â° to 180Â°)

Reference angle = 180Â° - 135Â° = 45Â°

tan(135Â°) = -tan(45Â°) = -1 (negative in Q II)

ðŸŽ¯ The Big Picture

The unit circle extends trigonometry from simple right triangles to all rotational motion. This foundation enables us to model waves, oscillations, and periodic phenomena in science and engineering!

), estimatedTime: 5 }, { id: 'lesson-summary', type: 'summary', title: "Unit Circle Mastery: You are Ready for Advanced Applications!", content: (

ðŸŽ‰ Phenomenal! You've Unlocked the Power of the Unit Circle

ðŸ† What You've Mastered:

  • âœ… Unit circle setup and coordinate system
  • âœ… How sine and cosine become coordinates
  • âœ… The four quadrants and their properties
  • âœ… ASTC sign pattern for all functions
  • âœ… Reference angles and symmetry principles
  • âœ… Working with angles beyond 90Â°
  • âœ… Coterminal angles and periodicity
  • âœ… Special angle values in all quadrants

ðŸŽ¯ Your New Superpowers:

Any Angle

Find trig values for any angle, positive or negative

Quadrant Navigation

Instantly know which functions are positive/negative

Reference Angles

Use symmetry to find any special angle value

ðŸš€ Coming Up Next:

Now that you understand how trigonometric functions work on the unit circle, you're ready to see them come alive as graphs:

  • â€¢ Graphing sine, cosine, and tangent functions
  • â€¢ Understanding amplitude, period, and phase shifts
  • â€¢ Seeing the wave patterns that connect to real-world phenomena
  • â€¢ Discovering why trigonometry is the language of oscillations

ðŸ’¡ The Connection Revolution

You've just experienced one of mathematics' most beautiful connections: how circular motion creates wave patterns. This insight connects geometry, algebra, and physics - and it's the foundation for understanding everything from sound waves to quantum mechanics!

), estimatedTime: 3 } ] }; interface TrigonometryUnitCircleMicroLessonProps { onComplete?: () => void; } const TrigonometryUnitCircleMicroLesson: React.FC = ({ onComplete }) => { return ( ); }; export default TrigonometryUnitCircleMicroLesson;

import * as React from "react" import * as NavigationMenuPrimitive from "@radix-ui/react-navigation-menu" import { cva } from "class-variance-authority" import { ChevronDown } from "lucide-react" import { cn } from "@/lib/utils" const NavigationMenu = React.forwardRef< React.ElementRef, React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef >(({ className, children, ...props }, ref) => ( {children} )) NavigationMenu.displayName = NavigationMenuPrimitive.Root.displayName const NavigationMenuList = React.forwardRef< React.ElementRef, React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef >(({ className, ...props }, ref) => ( )) NavigationMenuList.displayName = NavigationMenuPrimitive.List.displayName const NavigationMenuItem = NavigationMenuPrimitive.Item const navigationMenuTriggerStyle = cva( "group inline-flex h-10 w-max items-center justify-center rounded-md bg-background px-4 py-2 text-sm font-medium transition-colors hover:bg-accent hover:text-accent-foreground focus:bg-accent focus:text-accent-foreground focus:outline-none disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:opacity-50 data-[active]:bg-accent/50 data-[state=open]:bg-accent/50" ) const NavigationMenuTrigger = React.forwardRef< React.ElementRef, React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef >(({ className, children, ...props }, ref) => ( {children}{" "} )) NavigationMenuTrigger.displayName = NavigationMenuPrimitive.Trigger.displayName const NavigationMenuContent = React.forwardRef< React.ElementRef, React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef >(({ className, ...props }, ref) => ( )) NavigationMenuContent.displayName = NavigationMenuPrimitive.Content.displayName const NavigationMenuLink = NavigationMenuPrimitive.Link const NavigationMenuViewport = React.forwardRef< React.ElementRef, React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef >(({ className, ...props }, ref) => (
)) NavigationMenuViewport.displayName = NavigationMenuPrimitive.Viewport.displayName const NavigationMenuIndicator = React.forwardRef< React.ElementRef, React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef >(({ className, ...props }, ref) => (
)) NavigationMenuIndicator.displayName = NavigationMenuPrimitive.Indicator.displayName export { navigationMenuTriggerStyle, NavigationMenu, NavigationMenuList, NavigationMenuItem, NavigationMenuContent, NavigationMenuTrigger, NavigationMenuLink, NavigationMenuIndicator, NavigationMenuViewport, }

Replace the `\` with `\\` to include the actual backslash character.
